Assignments are brutal, always cutting on nursing staff and working with the bare minimum or below the minimum because it's always all about finances.

review_title: Decent place to learn admin but not for long term
pros:
No micro managing, not being constantly watched.
Free food sometimes from pharmaceutical advertisers.
Helping patients, knowing you made a difference in their treatment and diagnosis.
cons:
Disorganized, learn as you go type of environment.
Not up to date with technology, we deal with so much paper.
No life and work balance, hard to enjoy a vacation of day off when there are always pending orders to worry about.
Short Staffing, we have many doctors and not enough man power on the administrative side, when one person takes off work piles up.

pros: Benefits comprabable to local health systems, mostly 9-5

pros: Avoid it. None at all.
cons: SVPs, VPs, and Directors are all very demanding. They just sit in their offices all day making phone calls and sending emails to bark orders. You will have ten or even a plus of them above you. No one knows how busy you are since they don't communicate well with each other. They are not interested in their subordinate's happiness and career development,  so they will throw you under a bus to protect their hides. A very disrespectful environment where everyone only cares about themselves: you get hired for one position and end up doing the job for 5. Some tenants are tough to work with; some could scream at you for no reason. Most important, be prepared to be buried under the paper as the technology here is very old-school.

pros: Friendly work environment, great director

pros: I've worked here for over 5 years. There are a lot of friendly people who work here. The neighborhood is a pretty decent one. Cafeteria food is Kosher, tasteful and a healthy choice. An RN can earn a vast amount of experience with very critical illnesses due to the population it is serving and the direction that healthcare is taking hospital settings.
cons:
Staffing is very inadequate, which provides for a very unhappy work environment. The union can only help so much, and staff are being penalized for using time-off that they have rightfully accrued, although there are the outliers who abuse the time-off system.

There are a lot of employees who are lazy, which kills it for us hard workers. 

Not much of a selection in cafeteria food. To get a variety of food means that you have to walk for 5-7 minutes outside and in the winter or rain it's treacherous!

pros: Wonderful facility in the middle of Brooklyn that takes care of employees!

pros: Good leader and management.. Excellent colleagues.
cons: Pay scale a bit low

pros: The benefits and vacation were the best part of working at Maimondies hospital. Okay pentition plan and health benefits were very cheap. It is very interesting to work in a hospital and learn about medicine. The Human Resource department offered a lot of discounts at Amusement parks and cell phone companies. Every year we got a 3 percent raise. Every employess was give a pager. It was very easy to make plans for vacation. We were give generous amount of sick days and personal days. There a garage for the employess to use and the price was cheap. There was also a cafeteria that was cheap
cons: The pay was horrible and unfair compared to other hospitals in NYC. The doctors were very rude when you had to service their computer. No overtime and no communication within the MIS department. When I left they didnt  try to make me stay or make me an offer. Made a lot of promises and didnt come through with any. The MIS department had two separate locations one in the hospital and the other in a different building 10 blocks away. So we were split up. Didnt know what different teams were working on. The staff was kept in the dark about a lot of things.

review_title: Good colleagues, eccentric leadership, but poised for greatness
pros: Some wonderful people work at Maimonides because they sincerely want to make a real difference in the world. Many docs who could be working at NYU or NYP stay at Maimonides because they like the diversity of patients and the unique Brooklyn vibe. Strong in cancer and cardiac, rivaling the big academic medical centers in Manhattan. Profitable for last 10 years.
cons: The CEO. Pam Brier has stayed on too long and no one has the heart to tell her. She makes many irrational decisions and often pits staff against each other by spinning the truth. Bulk of other senior admin are at, or close to, retirement age, so there is a strong sense that many VPs are hanging on until they hit 65. Likely to be a lot of turnover in the C-suite in the next two years. If you are considering Maimonides for your residency, however, you won't regret going there. Never a dull moment but in a good way.

pros: Uses a mixture of new and old technologies. Good learning opportunity. You can gain good solid experience here to put on your resume. You will gain an insight into how IT department operates in a large hospital will a many remote sites.
cons: Management is aggressive and hostile. You get yelled at in front of your co-workers for making mistakes or doing something that management doesn't like. The stress level at this job is very high so you need to have a very thick skin to work at this job. The management talks down to employees, makes nasty comments and discourages any suggestions, changes or innovations. You will be harshly judged for even minor mistakes and not appreciated for any of your hard work at all. It appears that it all rolls downhill from the upper management and it's a pattern in this company's culture.

pros:
None unless you live in the area and do not have to 
travel into the city.  If you are a poor performer you can probably work there a long time because they do not get rid of poor employees they just keep transferring them to other departments.
cons: The place is absolutely filthy! Not only the hospital but all the brownstone offices. The place looks like Florence Nightingale completed her clinical training there and no upgrades have been done since. They do not give merit raises instead senior leadership never take a cut yet create smoke screens to claim financial loses and use that as an excuse to reduce staff dumping more work on everyone else. Even if you live in the area do yourself a favor, get the metro card and go to MANHATTAN to a REAL hospital.

review_title: Take my advise do not work in the MIS department
pros: Maimonides has some of the most extensive computerization of the patient care record in the country. The MIS department is convenient to public transportation.
cons: Management operates from the view that bullying is good and does not know how to interact with a professional staff. It is difficult to create a team to work on improvements and go-lives because it is like a revolving doors. Some project managers are worse than others and therefore their team is constantly changing. It is not uncommon to have an 8 am meeting scheduled on the same day as a 5 pm meeting for a 9-5 position. Then management will call you in and ask why you left 5 minutes early. 'My or the highway' is a phrase often heard within the confines of the former auto garage, now the MIS department, across the street from live chicken industry..

pros: I learned an enormous amount when working at Maimonides. The patient population is diverse making everyday an adventure. There are many opportunities to learn. The majority of the staff was very nice and helpful.
cons: My direct supervisor who is quite high up in the hierarchy, was abusive and difficult throughout my sojourn. Even worse was her secretary, who was actually running the show. I was promised an abundance of help when I began working at Maimonides and received none of it. I was however, criticized quite often along the way, almost to the point of producing tears. The people with whom I worked seemed to think that work/life balance was not important.

pros: Higher pay than some manhattan hospitals,  union, decent benefits. Emergency room is very busy, about 500 patients a day, especially flu season. Great for cadiology, cath lab on premesis. Great stroke team, lots of learning opportunities.  Oh yeah, we are also trying to get trauma accreditations now.
cons: Somewhat disorganized, very busy at times. We are sometimes so busy and/ or under staffed which causes more call outs because the staff is burnt out. Staffing is Probably An Issue everywhere though.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Brooklyn, NY
pros: Great pay without a college degree, union benefits, 4 weeks vacation per year, lots of overtime if you want extra cash, and health benefits.
cons: Mandatory overtime, intense micromanagement, cold people that have been there for years and hate it but it's their job so they stay miserable. No room for growth unless you become a pharmacist

review_title: Disgusting colleagues, lying, and rude patients
pros: Great health benefits for 1199 members,  when you make 5 years you get 4 weeks vacation, flexible and understanding Manager when it comes to work schedule and family issues. Manager/Supervisor will work with staff.
cons:
You have staff that have been at the company who refuse to learn other colleagues work, they pick
and choose what they want to learn. 
If you are computer savvy they try to get you
to teach them how to use the program(s) in the department when they have an MIS department who 
has staff who is specialized in assisting. 
If you are quiet or do not like confrontation they allow other staff members to harass, talk to you how they may normally speak to a family member at home. 
In addition, if you are a new person and you are capable of learning different area's of jobs in the department it now is expected of you to perform that job when the usual person who does the job may have called out sick or is on vacation or has a personal day off. The job function isn't rotated between staff who has been their for a long time and someone who is new. 
The patients lie and cheat the system and if you realize it the patients attempt to make you feel like you are crazy for even bringing it to their attention. When systems are running slow or you are taking care of a cuurent patient, the new patient isn't understanding of the issue with the system, or they become very inpatient and rude with you.

pros: Excellent Maternety experience, there is an unreal number of babies being born here.  There is something new every day, and I really enjoyed that.
cons: Some of the patients were not as welcoming of a male nurse on the maternity floor.  Which kinda makes sense...I don't let it hurt my feelings.  This place is a baby factory, if someone doesn't want your presence due to gender, wait 9 minutes and attend to the delivery down the hall.

pros: 1199SEIU Union. If it wasn't for the Union benefits I would quit long time ago. This is the best Union with full med coverage ( vision, dental included) . Also there is a Child Fund that covers summer sleep away camp and other activities.
cons: No room for growth. Business oriented company. They only care about the patient flow... Co-workers only care about themselves. A lot of back stubbing and gossiping is going on. No team work.

pros: None at all. You can come with a big heart, but hard work is not enough.
cons: Too much politics and the upper management has no respect for employees. Politics even affect the normal course of routine decisions

review_title: maimonides does not respect our title we fall under nursing and we do not get the respect deserved like a nurse does.
pros: Its a job and i get a paycheck, i get medical covarage, with some other perks.
cons: Maimonides has alot of money for the hosp for remodeling exp.the lobby but staff is understaffed over worked and under payed.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Chicago, IL
pros: This is as close as it gets to employers knocking on your door. If a job ad is being distributed by email, the employer is reaching out. These could be sent to, and come to you through, Career Services, your academic department, advisors, clubs, you name it.
cons: None, really. It's just a form of information and communication coming to you. Even if a particular job/career fields is not of interest, use it to learn about what is out there.

pros: Challenging work, potential to learn many different programs across the enterprise.  team work on various simultaneous projects.  Fast paced.
cons: Shrinking staff, increased workload. Not enough time to actually learn any one thing thoroughly.  No pay for working overtime. needs improvement

pros: Local institution with long Brooklyn history. Many long-time front-line staff care about the place, the patients and each other
cons: Crazy politics. Changes poorly communicated to staff. Getting harder to keep up with large hospital groups competing in Brooklyn.

review_title: Feels like you're working at a place that is 10 years behind the rest of the city
pros:
-I worked in External Affairs so my position was completely unrelated to administering care, but it seemed like most of the hospital offered truly great medical care. 

-Health benefits were excellent.
cons: Low pay. High turnover. Limited train service nearby. Few options for food in the area. Many New Yorkers are completely unfamiliar with Maimonides.

review_title: Poor Management, Nobody cares about patients
pros: Pros: Some perks (discounts, movie tickets) on the MMC intranet.
cons: It's mainly about who you know and not your skill set. Extremely poor management - doing things on the clock which do not pertain to the job. They push tasks off to others instead of handling themselves. Most employees working at MMC are only there for a paycheck. MMC is almost like a high school.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Staff members are friendly with one another for the most part. However it is clear which staff members are not as productive as the others and thus these members are not liked by the others.
cons: Specific departments are extremely understaffed and overworked. The hospital expects a handful of staff members to deal with an unreasonable amount of patients and paperwork.

review_title: Sr. Mgmt: Incompetent, Petty, Maybe Financially Corrupt. You Do NOT Want a Job Here!
pros: Some Middle Mgmt & co-workers decent, kind, people to work with. But many, back stabbers & worse    Most Nursing/Medical staff are ok.
cons: Upper Mgmt only interest is to keep cushy hi-paying jobs & treat workers like garbage. Make dumb deals with outside vendors for tons of money that lines their pockets.

review_title: I worked through the volunteer department, which was sent to other departments for any help with tasks or errands.
pros: Very friendly and welcoming environment. Employees at the MMC and Mail-room departments are very helpful and understanding.
cons: I was sent to two departments because of the unorganized work distribution.

pros: Its wonderful if you are in the inner circle
cons: It is a very unhealthy toxic bullying environment.  If you should fall from grace of the inner circle there are no boundaries to what they will do for their own benefit; including attempting to tarnish a stellar reputation as indicated by annual reviews.

pros: I learned the ability to make sound decisions based on valid information the capacity to learn and apply new information quickly and accurately.
cons: No growth, under staff, under pay, and no challenge

review_title: What I thought would be a dream job turned into a nightmare.
pros: Good community hospital in a great neighborhood in Brooklyn.
cons: Weak protections for employees.  I went to Human Resources because I felt my boss was abusive and emotionally unstable.  Colleagues had told me my boss had a history of picking on one person in the office.  HR never helped me and my boss fired me within days of my "confidential" meeting with HR.

job_title: Office Manager/SECY III in Staten Island, NY
pros: Maimonides Medical Center is a quality place to work.  I've had many positive experiences and have enjoyed the opportunity to serve the community.
cons: There are limited opportunities for a union employee to advance past a certain level.  Perhaps the institution should consider the career path of the union employee.

pros:
Good experience 
One day of  orientation to get to know the place and people
A lot of nice co-workers
cons:
Nurses constantly ignore patients
There are some mean supervisors
Most work are just filing

pros: The only reason I work for this hospital is Union benefits. We have 1199 SEIU Hospital Workers Union which is one of the best unions in New York. City.
cons: No room for advancement. Management doesn't encourage the staff to grow within the company.

pros: Lenient work schedule, as long as one gets the shift covered and maintain 40 hours you can take off. I do not know about now, however, when I was employed it was like a big family.
cons: Bias at times towards those who are not part of the community.

pros: good salary,  and no micromanagement
cons: no proper supervision, high turnover of colleagues and directors, very heavy and stressful caseload. No control over the schedule. Employees do not feel like management cares about them

pros:
Generous paid vacation and sick time
Supervision and staff vary greatly via department
Overall a good place to work for a limited time and for entry level staff
cons:
Unprofessional atmosphere
Very little continuing education support for non-residents
Physicians are very self-centered

pros: get all observed Jewish holidays, paid time off. Lots of great restaurants close by to have lunch. close to public transportation. Very diverse neighborhood, staff
cons: not enough raises or opportunites to grow or promotions. Parking is always horrible in the neighborhood. Preferential treatment in administration, especially dept of surgery.

review_title: Not the best not the worst

pros: Good residency training program at this hospital.
cons: Was not able to get residency training at this hospital even I have volunteered at this hospital. Even was not invited to interview.

pros: We believe in team work, and have great work relationships at this facility.
